trans-unit.source: File format for input and output

seg-source.mrk: File format for input and output

target.mrk: File format for input and output

trans-unit.source: There are specific requirements for the format of the input and output files when you import and export data.

seg-source.mrk: There are specific requirements for the format of the input and output files when you import and export data.

target.mrk: There are specific requirements for the format of the input and output files when you import and export data.

trans-unit.source: The default file format is a delimited text file with the following characteristics:

seg-source.mrk: The default file format is a delimited text file with the following characteristics:

target.mrk: The default file format is a delimited text file with the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: Rows are separated by a newline

seg-source.mrk: Rows are separated by a newline

target.mrk: Rows are separated by a newline

trans-unit.source: Fields are separated by a comma (<codeph>,</codeph>)

seg-source.mrk: Fields are separated by a comma (<codeph>,</codeph>)

target.mrk: Fields are separated by a comma (<codeph>,</codeph>)

trans-unit.source: Character-based fields are delimited with double quotes (<codeph>"</codeph>)

seg-source.mrk: Character-based fields are delimited with double quotes (<codeph>"</codeph>)

target.mrk: Character-based fields are delimited with double quotes (<codeph>"</codeph>)

trans-unit.source: Before you perform import or export operations, you must ensure that the chosen delimiter character is not contained in the data to be imported or exported. If you chose a delimiter character that is part of the data to be imported or exported, unexpected errors might occur. The following restrictions apply to column and character delimiters:

seg-source.mrk: Before you perform import or export operations, you must ensure that the chosen delimiter character is not contained in the data to be imported or exported.
If you chose a delimiter character that is part of the data to be imported or exported, unexpected errors might occur.
The following restrictions apply to column and character delimiters:

target.mrk: Before you perform import or export operations, you must ensure that the chosen delimiter character is not contained in the data to be imported or exported.
If you chose a delimiter character that is part of the data to be imported or exported, unexpected errors might occur.
The following restrictions apply to column and character delimiters:

trans-unit.source: Delimiters are mutually exclusive

seg-source.mrk: Delimiters are mutually exclusive

target.mrk: Delimiters are mutually exclusive

trans-unit.source: A delimiter cannot be a line-feed character, a carriage return, or a blank space

seg-source.mrk: A delimiter cannot be a line-feed character, a carriage return, or a blank space

target.mrk: A delimiter cannot be a line-feed character, a carriage return, or a blank space

trans-unit.source: The default decimal point (<codeph>.</codeph>) cannot be a character delimiter

seg-source.mrk: The default decimal point (<codeph>.</codeph>) cannot be a character delimiter

target.mrk: The default decimal point (<codeph>.</codeph>) cannot be a character delimiter

trans-unit.source: Delimiters cannot be hexadecimal characters (0-9, a-f, A-F).

seg-source.mrk: Delimiters cannot be hexadecimal characters (0-9, a-f, A-F).

target.mrk: Delimiters cannot be hexadecimal characters (0-9, a-f, A-F).

trans-unit.source: The record delimiter is assumed to be a newline character. The record delimiter should not be used as any other delimiter.

seg-source.mrk: The record delimiter is assumed to be a newline character.
The record delimiter should not be used as any other delimiter.

target.mrk: The record delimiter is assumed to be a newline character.
The record delimiter should not be used as any other delimiter.

trans-unit.source: Character delimiters are permitted with the character-based fields (CHAR, VARCHAR, and LONG VARCHAR) of a file during import. Any pair of character delimiters found between the enclosing character delimiters is imported into the database. For example, suppose that you have the following character string:

seg-source.mrk: Character delimiters are permitted with the character-based fields (CHAR, VARCHAR, and LONG VARCHAR) of a file during import.
Any pair of character delimiters found between the enclosing character delimiters is imported into the database.
For example, suppose that you have the following character string:

target.mrk: Character delimiters are permitted with the character-based fields (CHAR, VARCHAR, and LONG VARCHAR) of a file during import.
Any pair of character delimiters found between the enclosing character delimiters is imported into the database.
For example, suppose that you have the following character string:

trans-unit.source: "What a ""great"" day!"

seg-source.mrk: "What a ""great"" day!"

target.mrk: "What a ""great"" day!"

trans-unit.source: The preceding character string gets imported into the database as:

seg-source.mrk: The preceding character string gets imported into the database as:

target.mrk: The preceding character string gets imported into the database as:

trans-unit.source: What a "great" day!

seg-source.mrk: What a "great" day!

target.mrk: What a "great" day!

trans-unit.source: During export, the rule applies in reverse. For example, suppose you have the following character string:

seg-source.mrk: During export, the rule applies in reverse.
For example, suppose you have the following character string:

target.mrk: During export, the rule applies in reverse.
For example, suppose you have the following character string:

trans-unit.source: "The boot has a 3" heel."

seg-source.mrk: "The boot has a 3" heel."

target.mrk: "The boot has a 3" heel."

trans-unit.source: The preceding character string gets exported to a file as:

seg-source.mrk: The preceding character string gets exported to a file as:

target.mrk: The preceding character string gets exported to a file as:

trans-unit.source: "The boot has a 3""heel."

seg-source.mrk: "The boot has a 3""heel."

target.mrk: "The boot has a 3""heel."

trans-unit.source: The following example file shows four rows and four columns in the default file format:

seg-source.mrk: The following example file shows four rows and four columns in the default file format:

target.mrk: The following example file shows four rows and four columns in the default file format:

trans-unit.source: 1,abc,22,def 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,b and c are both null,,

seg-source.mrk: 1,abc,22,def 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,b and c are both null,,

target.mrk: 1,abc,22,def 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,b and c are both null,,

trans-unit.source: The export procedure outputs the following values:

seg-source.mrk: The export procedure outputs the following values:

target.mrk: The export procedure outputs the following values:

trans-unit.source: 1,"abc",22,"def" 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,"b and c are both null",,

seg-source.mrk: 1,"abc",22,"def" 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,"b and c are both null",,

target.mrk: 1,"abc",22,"def" 22,,,"a is a zero-length string, b is null" 13,"hello",454,"world" 4,"b and c are both null",,
